title: 105_hr4539
content: The "Consular Review Act of 1998" establishes a Board of Visa Appeals under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of State establishes a Board of Visa Appeals composed of 5 members, with no more than 2 being consular officers. The Board has authority to review discretionary decisions of consular officers regarding immigrant and nonimmigrant visas, as well as waiver applications for inadmissibility. If the Board finds a decision contrary to the evidence, it can overrule or remand it for further consideration. The Board of Visa Appeals can overrule or remand decisions made by consular officers if they are contrary to the evidence. Proceedings before the Board must follow regulations set by the Secretary of State, ensuring notice to all parties involved and providing a written record of the decision. Upon request for review, the Board must notify the consular officer within 30 days. The Board of Visa Appeals reviews decisions made by consular officers upon request from the alien or interested parties. The appellant must be given notice of the proceedings and can choose their own counsel at no cost to the Government. Requests for review must be made in writing within 60 days of receiving notice of denial, revocation, or cancellation. The Board of Visa Appeals reviews decisions made by consular officers upon request from the alien or interested parties, including the petitioner or beneficiary of immigrant visa petitions, petitioner of nonimmigrant visa petitions, postsecondary educational institutions, recognized international agencies, and treaty investors or traders in the United States. The Board of Visa Appeals reviews decisions made by consular officers upon request from interested parties, including treaty investors or traders in the United States. Requests for review are limited to once every 24 months, and fees may be charged for the review process. Effective dates for the amendment are specified in the legislation. The Board of Visa Appeals will have members appointed within 120 days of the Act's enactment. Technical amendments include changes to sections 222(f) and 104(a)(1) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The table of contents will be updated accordingly.
